awd_titl_txt: Viscoelastic and Viscoplastic Behavior of Thin Metal Films for MEMS
awd_abstract_narration:
This research is about the basic mechanisms that underlie a problem that often exists with the metals in micro-electromechanical devices used for applications like cell phones. Although the behavior of these tiny metal components may be fine immediately after fabrication, over time the behavior can change and the device may fail. In particular, the required tension that exists in certain metallic components can gradually relax, much like a guitar string relaxes over time. Unlike a guitar string, however, it is not possible to periodically tighten a metallic micro-electromechanical component to regain optimum functionality. A number of workaround solutions have been found, but the lack of basic understanding leads to greater device complexity, greater cost, and less capability than would otherwise be possible. The approach of this research is to systematically explore the root cause of the undesirable behavior by altering aspects of metal structure one at a time while holding the other aspects constant. Gold films approximately one micrometer thick will serve as a model system that can be modified on the surface and in the interior in order to simulate conditions that are common to other metals used in micro-electromechanical devices, including aluminum, copper, and platinum. 

If successful, the benefits of this research will include a greatly improved understanding of the undesirable time-dependent changes in metals used for micro-electromechanical devices. This will guide future development of metallic alloys and surface treatments to reduce or eliminate time-dependent changes. Mathematical descriptions of the trends observed in this research will provide device designers with the modeling tools needed to accelerate device development and reduce cost while doing so.  With a micro-electromechanical devices market of approximately $12 billion US dollars in 2012, influencing even a fraction of devices can have a significant economic effect. In particular, micro-electromechanical devices for cell phones, small displays, and automotive radars will benefit. Concepts related to micro-electromechanical devices and the methods used in this research will be shared with children in grades K-12 through an annual outreach event, stimulating their interest in science and engineering.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Thin metal films are often present in microelectronic and micromechanical devices. Over time, the mechanical behavior of the metal films can change through a process called stress relaxation.

This is a particular problem in applications such as electromechanical switches for radio frequency devices like cell phones and radars. If the performance of the device depends on consistent behavior of a metal film then stress relaxation can cause the device to deviate from the expected performance parameters and potentially even fail. The project addresses the need to mitigate such stress relaxation by identifying the underlying mechanisms responsible for the phenomenon. Once the mechanisms are clearly identified then mitigation approaches can be selected and optimized. We have found that one potential mitigation approach proposed by others – that of adding a thin surface layer – is ineffective under the conditions that typically exist in most micromechanical devices. We have also demonstrated that eliminating the internal "grain" boundaries that are typically present in thin metal films is not a useful way to eliminate relaxation, so the difficult task of fabricating "single crystal" films is not something that needs to be done. Instead, we have shown that increasing the number of grain boundaries, either through low-temperature film fabrication or through alloying, is an effective means of reducing relaxation. This is an easily-accomplished approach to reducing the deleterious effects of stress relaxation. Finally, we have also demonstrated that a common model for stress relaxation that works with many polymers can accurately describe the metal films that might be found in microelectronic and micromechanical devices. This makes it possible to use standard computational modeling tools to incorporate our stress relaxation results into sophisticated simulations.

One Ph.D. student and one M.S. student performed the majority of the work. They were assisted by a second Ph.D. student and an undergraduate student. The M.S. student has graduated and has taken a job in industry. The Ph.D. students will be graduating in the next few months. All have given a number of professional presentations describing their results. Together with a visiting scientist, they have produced one published paper with three more that are anticipated.

There have been several outreach activities intended to reach members of the local community and the undergraduate population at Lehigh University. The primary purpose of these outreach events is enhancing public understanding and increasing interest in learning and careers in science and engineering. For example, the PI and graduate students participated in Lehigh's Summer Engineering Institute (SEI) for three years. The SEI is a four-week summer residential program of intensive classroom study and research for exceptionally talented, rising high school juniors and seniors. It engaged 50 high school students from diverse backgrounds in a series of stimulating engineering activities. Together with a colleague in the Lehigh University Design program, the PI created a multi-day laboratory experience that involved additive manufacturing, mechanical testing, computer aided design, and finite element analysis in the context of a hypothetical NASA manned Mars mission.

For several years the PI has also engaged incoming first-year Lehigh undergraduates in two extracurricular events focused on materials engineering. The first was a half-day hands-on activity for the Lehigh Women Engineers "PreLUsion" orientation event. The young women involved in the activity participated in a miniature version of a mechanical testing and design activity that is part of the normal sophomore core labs in the Materials major. The objective was to provide them with a sense of what they would be doing once they made it past the introductory courses typical of the first year in the engineering program. The second was a 1-hour lecture and discussion that engaged over 100 incoming students in the exploration of materials as significant enablers of technological progress. Examples were given of materials developments over thousands of years and the engineering progress that resulted. The students were then asked to identify and discuss a materials advance that they would welcome as a way of enhancing the performance or value of a product known to them. These introductory undergraduate programs were designed to attract and retain students in engineering, particularly young women.

 


Last Modified: 01/23/2018
Modified by: Richard P Vinci
